org.simplity.kernel.dm

Class Record

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.simplity.kernel.dm.Record
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Component

    public class Record
extends Object
implements Component
    This is the main part of our data model. Every piece of data that the application has to keep as part of "system of records" must be modeled into this. Data structures that are used as input to, or output from a service are modeled as records as well.

    It is common industry practice to have "physical data model" and "logical data model" for proper understanding. We encourage such designs before recording them using the Record concept.

    Record is a good candidate to represent any data structure that is used across components, even if it is not persisted.

      • createSheet

        public DataSheet createSheet(boolean forSingleRow,
                             boolean addActionColumn)
        create an empty data sheet based on this record
        Parameters:
        forSingleRow - true if you intend to store only one row. False otherwise
        addActionColumn - should we add a column to have action to be performed on each row
        Returns:
        an empty sheet ready to receive data

      • createSheet

        public DataSheet createSheet(String[] colNames,
                             boolean forSingleRow,
                             boolean addActionColumn)
        create an empty data sheet based on this record for a subset of fields
        Parameters:
        colNames - subset of column names to be included
        forSingleRow - true if you intend to use this to have just one row
        addActionColumn - should we add a column to have action to be performed on each row
        Returns:
        an empty sheet ready to receive rows of data

      • readMany

        public int readMany(DataSheet inSheet,
                    DataSheet outSheet,
                    DbDriver driver,
                    Value userId)
        read, in our vocabulary, is ALWAYS primary key based read. Hence we expect (at most) one row of output per read. If values has more than one rows, we read for primary key in each row.
        Parameters:
        inSheet - one or more rows that has value for the primary key.
        outSheet - sheet to which rows are to be extracted
        driver -
        userId - we may have a common security strategy to restrict output rows based on user. Not used as of now
        Returns:
        data sheet for sure. With data that is returned by the driver

      • readOne

        public int readOne(FieldsInterface inData,
                   DataSheet outData,
                   DbDriver driver,
                   Value userId)
        read, in our vocabulary, is ALWAYS primary key based read. Hence we expect (at most) one row of output per read. If values has more than one rows, we read for primary key in each row.
        Parameters:
        inData - one or more rows that has value for the primary key.
        outData - sheet to which data is to be extracted into
        driver -
        userId - we may have a common security strategy to restrict output rows based on user. Not used as of now
        Returns:
        number of rows extracted

      • saveOne

        public SaveActionType saveOne(FieldsInterface row,
                              DbDriver driver,
                              Value userId,
                              boolean treatSqlErrorAsNoResult)
        add, modify and delete are the three operations we can do for a record. "save" is a special convenient command. If key is specified, it is assumed to be modify, else add. Save
        Parameters:
        row - data to be saved.
        driver -
        userId -
        treatSqlErrorAsNoResult - if true, we assume that some constraints are set at db level, and sql error is treated as if affected rows is zero
        Returns:
        number of rows saved. -1 in case of batch, and the driver is unable to count the saved rows

      • getReady

        public void getReady()
        Description copied from interface: Component
        Components may have to set-up their shops after loading the attributes. Typically ensuring referential integrity, caching etc..

        In case of components having sub-components, it is generally a good idea to have setUp() only for the parent component, from where you may trigger set-up of child components

        Specified by:
        getReady in interface Component

      • createFromTable

        public static Record createFromTable(String schemaName,
                                     String qualifiedName,
                                     String tableName,
                                     DbToJavaNameConversion conversion,
                                     DataTypeSuggester suggester)
        crates a default record component for a table from rdbms
        Parameters:
        schemaName - null to use default schema. non-null to use that specific schema that this table belongs to
        qualifiedName - like modulename.recordName
        tableName - as in rdbms
        conversion - how field names are to be derived from columnName
        suggester - data type suggester
        Returns:
        default record component for a table from rdbms

      • createAllRecords

        public static int createAllRecords(File folder,
                                   DbToJavaNameConversion conversion)
        generate and save draft record.xmls for all tables and views in the rdbms
        Parameters:
        folder - where record.xmls are to be saved. Should be a valid folder. Created if the path is valid but folder does not exist. since we replace any existing file, we recommend that you call with a new folder, and then do file copying if required
        conversion - how do we form record/field names table/column
        Returns:
        number of records saved

      • getTableName

        public String getTableName()
        Returns:
        table name for this record

        public void setFields(Field[] fields)
        Parameters:
        fields -

                        List<FormattedMessage> errors)

        errors -
        Returns:

      • filterToJson

        public void filterToJson(Record inRecord,
                         FieldsInterface inData,
                         DbDriver driver,
                         boolean useCompactFormat,
                         ResponseWriter writer)
        Parameters:
        inRecord - record to be used to input filter fields
        inData - that has the values for filter fields
        driver -
        useCompactFormat - json compact format is an array of arrays of data, with first row as header. Otherwise, each row is an object
        writer - json writer to which we will output 0 or more objects or arrays. (Caller should have started an array. and shoudl end array after this call

      • fromSwagger

        public static Record fromSwagger(JSONObject schema,
                                 String recordName,
                                 String moduleName,
                                 String[] defNames)
        creates a record component based on schema specification from a swagger document
        Parameters:
        schema - non-null non-empty object with each attribute representing a field
        recordName - non-null simple name of the record
        moduleName - can be null. module name. Full name of record would be moduleName.recordNme
        defNames - default names
        Returns:
        record, or null in case the schema is not valid.
